data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various plants of the genus Vaccinium, having white to reddish, urn-shaped or tubular flowers and edible blue to blue-black berries, especially the highbush blueberry and the lowbush blueberry.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The fruit of any of these plants.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A usually blue-gray spherule that is found in soil and sedimentary rock and is rich in hematite, produced by the weathering of rock or by precipitation from rock by moving groundwater.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: In America: The fruit of several species of Vaccinium, ordinarily distinguished from the various kinds of huckleberry by its blue color and smaller seeds. The swamp or tall blueberry is the Vaccinium corymbosum; the low blueberry, V. vacillans; and the dwarf blueberry, V. Pennsylvanicum. See bilberry.
Another name of the cohosh, Caulophyllum thalictroides.
In Australia: The fruit of the blueberry-tree, or the tree itself.
The berry-like fruit of Dianella lævis, of the lily family.

The berry of several species of Vaccinium, an ericaceous genus, differing from the American huckleberries in containing numerous minute seeds instead of ten nutlets. The commonest species are <spn>Vaccinium Pennsylvanicum</spn> and <spn>Vaccinium vacillans</spn>. <spn>Vaccinium corymbosum</spn> is the tall blueberry.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: An edible round <xref>berry</xref> belonging to the <xref>cowberry</xref> family. (A botanically false berry.) It has flared "crowns" at the end that turn blue on ripening.
